College of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Jiangsu University of Science and Technology Zhenjiang 212000 PR China The widespread application of Fe-based denitrification catalysts is limited by its unsatisfying low-temperature NO conversion and poor anti-SO2 ability. In this study, by virtue of FeSi composite oxide with large specific surface area as support and NbO x species was used for surface modification to further regulate their acidity and redox properties, significantly improving their NH3-SCR activity. The optimal Nb/FeSi catalyst exhibited over 90 % NO conversion at 250–400 °C and displayed excellent SO2 resistance at 225 °C. The characterization results revealed that Si doping induced an amorphous structure in the FeSi composite and facilitated the formation of distinctive Fe-O–Si bonding configurations. These structural features endowed the Nb/FeSi catalyst with both an enlarged specific surface area and increased Brønsted acid sites, facilitating the dispersion of active components and the activation of NH3 species. Nb could promote the generation of more oxygen vacancies and abundant Brønsted acid sites while inhibits the adsorption of NO x and SO2. Further mechanistic studies revealed that the enhanced Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism, where gaseous NO directly reacts with adsorbed NH₃, significantly promoted the NH₃-SCR efficiency of Nb/FeSi. This work provides experimental guidance to improve the activity and sulfur resistance of denitration catalyst by active component control. Graphical Abstract Keywords NO elimination Fe2O3 SiO2 NbO x Sulfur resistance Promoted mechanism Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction As a major atmospheric molecular pollutant, nitrogen oxides (NO x ) are mainly derived from the combustion of fossil fuels and high temperature processes involving air [1]. NO x is the main culprit of sour rain and photochemical smoke, and it is also an important cause of haze weather [2]. Ammonia selective catalytic reduction (NH3-SCR) technology is one of the most effective ways to eliminate NO at present [3]. Among them, the V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst is a commercial catalyst that is mainly used for NO elimination of coal -fired power plants. However, the V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst cannot be directly used as an efficient catalyst to eliminate NO directly from flue gases of other NO-emitting sources, such as iron and steel mills, glass mills, cement plants, and so on. This is because the emission temperature of these flue gas is low than 300 °C, which does not match the active temperature window of the V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst (350–420 °C) [4,5], and the SO2 in the flue gas is also easy to cause catalyst poisoning [6,7]. Therefore, developing industrial applications with more extensive and efficient low-temperature tolerant denitration catalysts that are resistant to SO2 poisoning has become a significant challenge. In recent years, researchers have found that catalysts containing Mn, Fe, Cu, and Ce, among others [6,8–10], have shown good low-temperature activity or certain advantages in resisting SO2 poisoning in NO elimination, and are expected to become denitration catalysts for industrial applications [4]. Among them, Fe2O3 has been valued and extensively studied in the NH3-SCR process due to its excellent redox performance, good sulfur resistance, low cost, and environmental friendliness [11]. However, the SCR reaction performance of Fe2O3 alone often has certain limitations due to its small specific surface area and weak surface acidity [12]. Therefore, some researchers have shifted their focus to the modification of Fe-based catalysts to improve their SCR performance. Catalysts such as Fe-Ce [13], Fe-Ti [14] and Fe-Mn [15] were developed and all showed better SCR performance compared to pristine Fe2O3. For example, Xiong et al. [16] prepared FeTi composite oxide catalysts and found that the improved denitrification performance was due to the introduction of Ti which increased the specific surface area, surface acidity and generated more redox active sites. Most of the previous researches have primarily focused on dispersing iron as an active component onto a support or incorporating other active components to form a composite multimetallic catalyst. However, there have been relatively few studies that specifically concentrate on surface modification of Fe2O3 to enhance its selective catalytic reduction (SCR) performance. In 2018, Liu et al. [17] was the first to employ WO3 as an additive for surface modification of Fe2O3 and discovered that the WO3/Fe2O3 catalysts with modified WO3 exhibited excellent SCR activity and sulfur resistance. The characterization results show that this is because the surface modification of WO3 not only significantly increases the surface acid sites of Fe2O3, but also regulates the redox ability of Fe2O3 and inhibits the peroxidation of NH3. However, as a catalyst support, pristine Fe2O3 still has the disadvantages of small specific surface area and easy agglomeration at high temperature. SiO2 is usually used as an additive to improve the physicochemical properties of some supports, such as CeSi [18] and TiSi [19]. The addition of Si can make CeO2 and TiO2 form more lattice defects, which can not only significantly increase its specific surface area, but also produce more oxygen vacancies and acid sites, which will play a positive role in enhancing the SCR activity of the catalyst. In addition, compared with commercial V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalysts, the active temperature window of Fe-based catalysts shifts towards lower temperatures and exhibits better resistance to SO2 poisoning at low temperatures. However, the small surface area and narrow temperature window of many Fe-based catalysts limit their further industrial applications. Niobium oxides (NbO x ) with high acid strength has recently been used as additives to improve SCR performance. For example, Qu et al. [20] prepared CeNb composite oxides and found that CeNb composite oxides exhibited better SCR performance than pure CeO2, which was mainly due to the high acidity caused by Nb addition and the enhanced redox performance caused by Ce-Nb interaction. Zhang et al. [21] prepared FeNb composite oxides with high specific surface area by CTAB, and found that the excellent SCR performance of FeNb was derived from the increase of specific surface area and the strong interaction between Fe and Nb, which induced more reduced Fe at low temperature. Ma et al. [22] loaded NbO x onto pure CeZr composite oxides and found that 15 wt% Nb addition could maximise the SCR catalytic activity of CeZr to achieve 90 % NO conversion at 200 °C. In summary, adding NbO x is a convenient and useful method to improve the surface acidity properties of catalysts. Therefore, in this work, we attempted to modify NbO x on the surface of Fe-based catalysts due to the weak surface acidity of Fe species. The Fe-based DeNO x catalyst with the best NH3-SCR catalytic performance is obtained by optimizing the added Nb content. In this work, we used Si as a modifier to prepare large specific area FeSiO x composite oxides as support, and NbO x as a surface modifier to modify the FeSiO x support to further boost its NH3-SCR activity and SO2 resistance. The obtained catalysts were investigated in detail using XRD, BET, XPS, H2-TPR, NH3-TPD, NO-TPD and in situ DRIFTs to reveal the key factors for the superior catalytic performance of Nb/FeSi catalysts. It helps to further understand the iron-based catalysts and broaden their industrial applications in the medium-temperature NH3-SCR system. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation FeSiO x composite oxides were synthesized by a simple co-precipitation method using ferric nitrate hydrate and ethyl orthosilicate as the precursor salts and ammonia (25–28 %) as the precipitant. Ferric nitrate hydrate (Fe(NO3)3⋅9H2O)was dissolved in 50 ml of ethanol with full stirring, and tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) (the molar ratio of Fe/Si = 1/1) was added dropwise, stirred for 30 min, and then aqueous ammonia was added drop by drop to pH ≈ 10, stirred for 2 h and then aged overnight, and the precipitates were washed by ethanol and water for several times, centrifuged, and dried at 80 ℃ overnight, and then baked at 450 ℃ for 4 h under air atmosphere to obtain the FeSiO x composite, abbreviated as FeSi. The same method was used to prepare iron oxide, abbreviated as Fe. The catalysts loaded with NbO x were prepared by a simple wet impregnation method using the obtained FeSi and Fe as supports and niobium acetate as a precursor salt. A certain amount of niobium acetate was accurately weighed and dissolved in 20 ml distilled water, then the prepared FeSi/Fe support was added, in which Nb accounted for 5–20 wt% of the mass of the support, stirred sufficiently, and the liquid was evaporated in an oil bath at 110 °C to a powder form, milled homogeneously, and then roasted at 450 °C for 4 h under an air atmosphere, which led to the preparation of Nb/Fe and Nb/FeSi catalysts. The catalysts with 5 wt% Nb, 10 wt% Nb, 15 wt% Nb, 20 wt% Nb were denoted as Nb/FeSi-5, Nb/FeSi-10, Nb/FeSi-15 and Nb/FeSi-20, respectively. The loading of Nb on pristine Fe was fixed at 10 wt%, abbreviated as Nb/Fe. 2.2 Activity tests 300 mg of catalyst pellets that had been pressed into 40–60 mesh was placed in fixed bed quartz tubes to test its NH3-SCR catalytic performance. The reaction conditions were 500 ppm NO, 500 ppm NH3, 200 ppm SO2 (when used), 5 vol% O2, 5 vol% H2O equilibrated with N2, and a total flow rate of 200 ml/min corresponding to a gas time-vacuum speed (GHSV) of 40,000 ml⋅g−1 h−1. The SCR reaction was carried out at 100–450 °C, and after equilibrium, the exhaust NO and the NO2, NH3, N2O concentration was determined by an online Thermofisher iS10 FTIR spectrometer equipped with a 2 m path-length gas cell (250 ml volume). The NO conversion rate and N2 selectivity were defined by the following equations: N O c onv ersion ( % ) = [ NO ] in − [ NO ] out [ NO ] in ✕ 100 % N 2 sel ectivity ( % ) = [ NO ] in + [ NH 3 ] in − [ NO ] out − [ NH 3 ] out − [ NO 2 ] out − 2 [ N 2 O ] out [ NO ] in + [ NH 3 ] in − [ NO ] out − [ NH 3 ] out ✕ 100 % 2.3 Catalyst characterization The crystal phases of the samples were identified by X-ray diffraction (XRD), Shimadzu XRD-6000 cu-k-α radiation source diffractometer. Signal strength data in the 2θ range of 5–8° were collected at a scanning speed of 5°/min and a step size of 0.02 °. BET specific surface area, total pore volume and average pore diameter were measured by nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherm at − 196 ℃. X-ray electron spectroscopy (XPS) is performed on the PHI 5000 Versa Probe X-ray photoelectron spectrometer. Monochromatic Al Kα radiation (1486.6 eV, 15 kW). XPS data analysis was performed using Thermo Scientific Avantage software. H2 programmed temperature reduction test (H2-TPR) was carried out on PCA-1200 chemical adsorbent (China). 100 mg samples were placed in U-shaped quartz tube, pretreated for 30 mins at 200 °C with Ar at a flow rate of 30 ml/min, and heated to 800℃ at a rate of 10 ℃/min under flowing H2/Ar. NH3 temperature programmed desorption test (NH3-TPD). 100 mg samples were placed in U-shaped quartz tube, pretreated for 30 mins at 200 °C with Ar at a flow rate of 30 ml/min, then NH3 was adsorbed and saturated with a flow rate of 30 ml/min, Ar purged until the physical adsorbed ammonia disappeared, and heated to 800 ℃ at a speed of 10 ℃/min to collect TCD signals. NO temperature programed desorption (NO-TPD) was carried out in a fixed-bed quartz flow reactor connected with an online flue gas analyser. Approximately 100 mg of each sample were pretreated by highly purified Ar at 200 °C for 1 h and were then saturated with NO + O2 at room temperature. The Ar was introduced into the quartz tube reactor again to remove the weakly adsorbed NO x . After that, the samples were heated to 600 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min in the flowing high purity Ar (100 ml/min). The microscopic morphology of the catalysts was analyzed using a ZEISS Sigma 360 scanning electron microscope (SEM), a JEM-2100plus field-emission transmission electron microscope (TEM). In situ diffuse reflection Fourier Transform infrared (DRIFT) experiments were performed with an MCT detector on the Nicolet Nexus 5700 FT-IR spectrometer, with an average of 32 scans and a resolution of 4 cm−1. Before collecting the background spectra, the samples were pretreated with high-purity N2 at 400 °C for 1 h. Background spectra were then collected in a flowing high-purity N2 stream as the powder samples cooled to the target temperature. The sample spectra were then obtained after the subtraction of the background spectra. The samples were exposed to a controlled stream of specific gas mixture for a certain amount of time: 1000 ppm NH3; 1000 ppm SO2 + 5 % O2; 1000 ppm NO + 5 % O2. All of the reaction gasses were balanced with N2 at a flow rate of 50 ml·min−1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 NH3-SCR activity and sulfur resistance The NH3-SCR activity result was presented in Fig. 1a, it can be seen that the pristine Fe displays poorly in the NH3-SCR activity test, achieving only about 33 % NO elimination efficiency at 250 °C. In addition, when the temperature rises above 350 °C, the NO conversion of Fe is negative, which may be due to the over-oxidation of NH3 [23]. With the addition of Si, the SCR activity of FeSi is improved in a certain extent, reaching 90 % NO conversion at 300 °C, but it is evident that the activity temperature window of FeSi catalyst is still very narrow. However, the Nb/Fe and Nb/FeSi samples exhibited significantly better SCR activity than the Fe and FeSi samples after modification of the Fe and FeSi surfaces with Nb. Comparing the Nb/FeSi catalysts with different Nb loadings, it can be found that the SCR performance of the Nb/FeSi catalysts shows an increasing and then decreasing trend with the increase of Nb loading amount. Among them, Nb/FeSi-10 showed the best catalytic activity, achieving 90 % NO conversion in the temperature interval of 250–400 ℃. In addition, the N2 selectivity of these prepared catalysts is also evaluated and the result is shown in Fig. S1. It is found that the N2 selectivity of these prepared catalysts is similar and decreases with increasing temperature. In addition, it was found that after adding Nb, the N2 selectivity of Nb/FeSi catalyst was better than that of Fe and FeSi, with over 90 % N2 selectivity in the temperature range of 150–400 °C. In order to be closer to the actual application conditions, SO2 resistance is also an important indicator of whether the denitration catalyst is excellent or not. Therefore, we investigated the stability of the catalyst against SO2 at 225 ℃, and the test results are depicted in Fig. 1b. It can be observed that the activity of the pristine Fe catalyst decreased significantly after the introduction of SO2 and almost no SCR activity after 12 h. For FeSi, Nb/Fe and Nb/FeSi-10 catalysts, the NO conversions decreased slowly after the introduction of SO2, which suggests that the introduction of Si and Nb can improve the anti-SO2 poisoning ability of Fe catalyst. Moreover, the activity of Nb/FeSi-10 catalyst remained the highest NO conversion of 96 % in 12 h after introducing SO2. The above results indicate that Fe species do have certain advantages in resistance to SO2 poisoning, which is keeping with the results reported in the previous studies [24,25]. At the same time, Nb/FeSi-10 showed higher NO conversion than Fe and Nb/Fe catalysts in 225 ℃ SO2 atmosphere, showing a certain industrial application potential. Moreover, we further investigated the influence of the coexistence of H2O and SO2 on the SCR activity of the synthesized catalysts and the result is presented in Fig. S2. After 200 ppm SO2 and 5 vol% H2O was added into reaction gas, the NO conversions of the prepared catalysts begin to slowly decrease, while the deactivation rate of the Nb/FeSi catalyst is the slowest. After 10 h of H2O + SO2 testing, the Nb/FeSi catalyst still remains a NO conversion of over 80 %. However, compared with the individual anti-SO2 test results of these catalysts, the co-introduction of H2O + SO2 has a stronger influence on the catalysts. In addition, the Nb/FeSi catalyst displayed excellent long-term stability, which remained about ∼ 98 % NO conversion within 72 h at 225 °C (Fig. S3). From the above NH3-SCR catalytic performance of these synthesized catalysts, it can be seen that the addition of Si and Nb has a significant impact on the NO conversion and SO2 poisoning resistance of Fe. Hence, the Fe, Nb/Fe, FeSi and Nb/FeSi-10 (denoted as Nb/FeSi in the following section) catalysts are characterized carefully to understand the main factors affecting the superior activity of Nb/FeSi catalyst. 3.2 Structural properties XRD was employed to analyze the crystalline structure of the obtained samples and the XRD profiles of Fe, Nb/Fe, FeSi and Nb/FeSi are shown in Fig. 2. Unlike the XRD pattern of pristine Fe, only a broad diffraction peak could be detected for FeSi, meaning the amorphous form of FeSi after the addition of Si. According to the literature [26], this is due to the fact that the doping of Si hinders the formation of the crystalline phase of FeO x , which is probably the main reason why we did not obtain the characteristic diffraction peaks of FeO x . This can be regarded as a strong evidence for the formation of strong Fe–O–Si bonds and short-range Si–O–Si bonds. After loading Nb, Nb/Fe and Nb/FeSi maintain their original crystal structure and no crystalline phase attributed to niobium oxide can be detected. This indicates that niobium oxide is dispersed on the corresponding support as a non-crystalline phase or the particle size is smaller than the XRD limitation. Moreover, the grain sizes of Fe and Nb/Fe were calculated using the Scherrer formula based XRD pattern. The results showed that the average particle sizes of Fe and Nb/Fe were 28.11 nm and 27.50 nm, respectively, which indicate that the introduction of Nb did not have an obvious impact on the particle size of Fe. Based on the N2 isothermal adsorption-desorption curve and the corresponding BJH pore size distribution curves of the prepared samples in Fig. 3, the textural data is summarized and presented in Table 1. As illustrated in Table 1, the specific surface area of pristine Fe catalyst is only 30.4 m2/g, and the specific surface area of FeSi greatly increase to 299.0 m2/g with the addition of Si into Fe, which is well-backed by previous report that silica is an efficient surface area stabilizer[27]. After the impregnation of Nb, the pore size of the Nb/Fe and Nb/FeSi was refined and the specific surface area reduced, which is mainly due to the blockage of surface pores by loading Nb species. The SEM and TEM images of Fe, Nb/Fe, FeSi, and Nb/FeSi need to be provided in Fig. S4 and Fig. S5. The results indicated that the pristine Fe2O3 was mainly present in irregular elliptical forms with particle sizes of approximately 30–50 nm. After doping Si, FeSi sample showed rough particle surfaces and presented amorphous phases, which was consistent with the XRD result. The SEM and TEM images of Nb/Fe and Nb/FeSi samples were similar with pristine Fe2O3 and FeSi, respectively, which suggested that the surface deposition of Nb species did not have a significant effect on the morphology of Fe and FeSi samples. Combined with the above results, an amorphous FeSi mixed oxide with high specific surface area was successfully synthesized and the texture property of pristine Fe and Nb/Fe catalysts is effectively improved by Si doping for the enlarged surface area and decreased grain size. This is beneficial for better dispersion and anchoring of active components, and can improve the durability of the catalyst. 3.3 Surface chemical state and redox properties To determine the valence state change and coordination environment of these catalyst, XPS characterization and corresponding analysis were conducted. The survey of XPS (Fig. S6 and Table 2) showed that all four catalyst samples contained O and Fe elements, in addition, FeSi contained Si element, Nb/Fe contained Fe element, and Nb/FeSi samples contained Nb and Si elements. The energy level spectra of O 1s, Fe 2p, Nb 3d and Si 2p of the catalyst were further analyzed in detail, as shown in Fig. 4. First, the spectra were charge-corrected by calibrating the adventitious carbon C 1s peak to a binding energy of 284.8 eV. Subsequently, the chemical species were identified and quantified through peak deconvolution using a mixed Gaussian-Lorentzian (Voigt) line shape. As shown in Fig. 4a, two main peaks are observed for O 1s spectra of the pristine Fe, which the peak located at low binding energy (∼ 529.5 eV) is assigned to lattice oxygen species and the peak at high binding energy (∼ 531.4 eV) is ascribed to surface chemical adsorption oxygen species including reactive oxygen species and hydroxyl like compounds [28]. According to the XPS result of SiO2, a highly symmetrical peak at about 532.7 eV was observed on SiO2 which is account for Si-O. Completely different from O 1s XPS for Fe2O3 or Nb/Fe, the O 1s XPS peak on FeSi and Nb/FeSi showed a broader peak shape and was located between the O 1s XPS peaks on Fe and SiO2. Based on this, it could be inferred that this unique O 1s XPS peak on FeSi and Nb/FeSi should be related to the oxygen atom in Fe-O-Si structure, confirming the strong interaction between Fe and Si. What’s more, after the introduction of Si, the surface oxygen content over FeSi and Nb/FeSi catalysts is markedly improved compared with Fe, Nb/Fe. Therefore, we can clearly infer that the increase in surface adsorbed oxygen content of FeSi and Nb/FeSi samples is due to the introduction of Si. In order to explore the interaction between Fe3+/Fe2+ species and Nb/ or Si in the catalysts, the Fe 2p XPS peaks of the catalysts are well analyzed. As shown in Fig. 4(b), the peak belonging to Fe 2p3/2 (∼ 710.4 eV) and the peak attributed to Fe 2p1/2 (∼ 724.6 eV) were observed for all samples, and the characteristic peak belonging to Fe3+ is also observed at ∼ 719.1 eV [29]. Compared to pristine Fe sample, it is worth noting that the peak positions of Nb/Fe, FeSi, and Nb/FeSi samples shift towards higher binding energies with the introduction of Si and Nb. We consider that this change is caused by the interaction between Fe and Si/or Nb, which can affect the electron cloud density of iron species [30]. Furthermore, the Fe 2p3/2 peaks of these catalysts are separated into two peaks, which are assigned to the Fe2+ and Fe3+ species. As the quantitative analysis results listed in Table 2, the relative concentration of Fe2+ in FeSi, Nb/Fe, and Nb/FeSi samples increased by comparison to pristine Fe. According to previous literature reported [31], the change of the content of intermediate valence states usually hints at an interaction between Fe species and Nb/ or Si species, which is contributed to improve the redox performance of these catalysts. Based on the XPS results of O 1s and Fe 2p, it can be inferred that the binding energy of Fe and Si in FeSi composite oxide is shifted compared to pristine Fe and SiO2, indicating the formation of Fe-O-Si structure. Previous literature [27] have indicated that the presence of M-O-Si structure can generate surface hydroxyl groups, which is beneficial for inhibiting the adsorption of SO2 on the catalyst surface. In addition, compared to SiO2, the Si 2p XPS peaks on FeSi and Nb/FeSi catalysts exhibited significant shifts simultaneously. At the same time, the introduction of Si also leads to a shift in the characteristic peak of Nb 3d towards higher binding energy, which well demonstrates the electron induction effect between Fe and Si and Nb. Based on the above XPS analysis results, we can find that the introduction of Nb and Si can affect the electron cloud density of around Fe species, while increase the amount of active species and surface hydroxyl groups on the catalyst, which is conducive to the redox process and the activation of NH3, and thus promote the process of NH3-SCR reaction. H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) technology is employed to evaluated the redox ability of the prepared catalysts, the obtained H2-TPR curves are presented in Fig. 5a. As previous studies reported [32,33] the pristine Fe exhibits two reduction peaks located at about 380 and 620 ℃, which are ascribed to the stepwise reduction of the iron oxide species (i.e., Fe2O3→Fe3O4 and Fe3O4→FeO→Fe). Moreover, the onset reduction temperatures of these catalysts were summarized in Fig. 5b, it can be observed that FeSi displayed an initial reduction temperature at about 270 ℃, which is lower than that of pristine Fe, suggesting the Fe-O component in the FeSi sample be more easily reduced by Si doping. However, the reduction peak temperatures of Nb/Fe and Nb/FeSi catalysts are respectively higher than those of pristine Fe and FeSi samples, indicating that the deposition of Nb onto the Fe or FeSi surface could delay the reduction of iron oxide species towards high temperature. Furthermore, we can find that the low-temperature reduction peak area of Si containing samples (FeSi and Nb/FeSi) (I/I + II peak area ratio) are significantly higher than those of pristine Fe and Nb/Fe samples, indicating that the introduction of Si could make more iron oxide species be reduced at low temperatures. This enhancement is mainly owing to the reduction of grain sizes and the existence of Fe–O–M bonds [19,34]. To summarize, Si doping could improve the reducibility of pristine Fe, while the deposition of Nb onto pristine Fe and FeSi surface inhibits the oxidation ability of bulk iron oxide. It was reported that the existence of bulk iron oxide can cause non-selective oxidation of NH3 in the NH3-SCR reaction, leading to a decrease in denitrification efficiency. And the deposition of acidic oxide WO3 on the surface of pristine Fe can significantly weaken the NH3 over-oxidation activity of bulk iron oxide [34,35]. As the individual NH3 oxidation reaction results shown in Fig. S7, the NH3 oxidation activity of Nb/Fe and Nb/FeSi samples deposition with Nb is significantly inhibited. As discussed above the H2-TPR results, the introduction of Nb and Si can significantly tune the reduction behavior of these prepared catalyst, which is conducive to improve the low-temperature NH3-SCR activity and inhibit the over-oxidation of NH3 at high temperatures. 3.4 Surface acid-base properties It is well known that the adsorption and activation of NH3 molecules is a key factor affecting the NH3-SCR catalytic activity. Consequently, NH3-temperature programmed adsorption-desorption (NH3-TPD) experiment was conducted to evaluated the surface acidic properties of these synthesized catalysts. The obtained NH3-TPD profiles are shown in Fig. 6, all the samples displayed two broad peaks within the test temperature region belonging to the desorption of NH3 molecules adsorbed on the catalysts surface. According to literatures reported [26,36], the desorption peak at lower temperature belongs to the desorption of NH3 species adsorbed on weak acid sites, while the desorption peak at higher temperature of about 300 ℃ is related to the desorption of NH3 species adsorbed on medium strong acid sites. The desorption peak area is considered to be proportional to the amount of surface acid sites and the integrated area of these NH3 desorption peaks are displayed in Table 2. We can find that the desorption peak area could be ranked in the order Nb/FeSi > FeSi > Nb/Fe > Fe, which indicates that the introduce of Si or Nb can both increase the surface acid sites of the pristine Fe catalyst. The enhancement is related to the increase in the specific area of the catalysts and the existence of Si-OH or Nb-OH. It is interesting that although the specific surface area of FeSi is much larger than that of Nb/FeSi, the Nb/FeSi sample possess more surface acid sites. Therefore, the Nb/FeSi catalyst with the most surface acid sites exhibited the best NH3-SCR catalytic activity. The NH3 adsorption and activation behavior are further characterized by in situ DRIFTS of NH3 adsorption experiment. As a result, the in situ DRIFTS experiments of NH3 adsorption-desorption over pristine Fe, FeSi, Nb/Fe and Nb/FeSi catalysts are conducted and the obtained results are displayed in Fig. 7. As presented in Fig. 7a, after NH3 adsorption and N2 purge, some infrared bands assigned to NH3 adsorbed species on pristine Fe were detected. According to literatures, the bands round 1601、1182 and 1141 cm−1 could be attributed to the asymmetric and symmetric bending vibrations of coordinated NH3 species on Lewis acid sites, and the infrared vibration band at 1547 cm−1 is ascribed to the monodentate nitrate species produced by NH3 oxidation[37]. All of these vibration bands decrease with the elevation of temperature. For FeSi sample in Fig. 7b, the DRIFTS spectra of NH3 adsorption on FeSi surface showed obviously different features from pristine Fe. After NH3 adsorption, we can find that the surface acid sites of Nb/FeSi are mainly Brønsted acid sites (1689 cm−1 and 1439 cm−1 attributed to Brønsted acid sites, 1610 cm−1 assigned to Lewis acid site), while the pristine Fe are mainly Lewis acid sites[38]. For Nb/Fe sample in Fig. 7c and Nb/FeSi sample in Fig. 7d, the large amount of Brønsted acid sites were also observed (1436 and 1650 cm−1 for Nb/Fe, 1439 and 1689 cm−1 for Nb/FeSi). According to previous literature[21,39], the Brønsted acid sites on the FeSi, Nb/Fe and Nb/FeSi surface mainly comes from the exposed NbO, Nb-OH and Si-OH sites because of the introduction of Nb and Si. Combining the NH3-SCR activity and NH3 adsorption results, we can clearly find that these catalysts possess more Brønsted acid sites than pristine Fe and they exhibit better SCR catalytic activity, which suggests that the increase of Brønsted acid sites is beneficial for enhancing its NH3-SCR activity. 3.5 NO x adsorption properties Fig. 8 shows the influence of the introduction of Nb and Si on the NO x adsorption behavior of Nb/FeSi catalyst. For pristine Fe catalyst (Fig. 8a), after NO + O2 adsorption and N2 purge, the intense infrared bands assigned to bridge nitrates (1603 cm−1, 1226 cm−1) and monodentate nitrates (1253 cm−1) are clearly detected at 50 ℃. The bands attributed to bidentate nitrates at 1567 cm−1 and 1532 cm−1 are also observed [40,41]. With the increase of temperature, the adsorbed bridge nitrate remained stable at 400 ℃. However, the band intensity of bidentate nitrates increased visibly, while the intensity of monodentate nitrates decreased, possibly due to the conversion of monodentate nitrates to more heat-stable bidentate nitrates. For FeSi catalyst (Fig. 8b), the infrared bands assigned to bridge nitrate (1606 cm−1), bidentate nitrate (1579 cm−1), monodentate nitrate (1302 cm−1) and nitro species (1346 cm−1) were detected after NO + O2 adsorption [42]. Obviously, it can be found that when the temperature rises from 50 ℃ to 400 ℃, the infrared band intensity of all kinds of nitrates adsorbed on FeSi catalyst gradually decreases and disappear at 400 ℃. Comparing the NO + O2 adsorption-desorption behavior of Fe and FeSi, the difference is that the adsorption strength of nitrates on Nb/FeSi catalysts is weaker and easier to desorption at high temperature. With regard to Nb/Fe (Fig. 8c) and Nb/FeSi (Fig. 8d), similarly, all the infrared bands for bridging nitrates, bidentate nitrates, monodentate nitrates and gaseous NO molecules are also observed at the corresponding positions, and the variation trend of these bands is very similar with those of FeSi catalyst. However, what is worth our attention is the band intensities of these adsorbed NO x species on the surface of Nb/Fe and Nb/FeSi catalysts are also weaker than those on the surface of pristine Fe. This indicates that the adsorption of NO x species on FeSi, Nb/Fe and Nb/FeSi catalyst is inhibited with Nb and Si introduced. According to previous studies [43,44], competitive adsorption usually exists between thermally stable nitrate species and NH3, which may inhibit the adsorption and activation of NH3 species. In order to further compare the content of adsorbed NO x species on the synthesized catalysts, the NO-TPD experiments are conducted. The catalyst was first saturated with NO + O2 adsorption at 30 °C, then purged with Ar, and finally the NO desorption curve of the catalyst between 30 and 600 °C was collected. As shown in Fig. 9, two obvious NO desorption peaks are observed on the NO-TPD profile of pure Fe catalyst. According to previous studies [45,46], the area of the desorption peak is linearly correlated with the amount of adsorbed nitrate species on the catalyst surface, so we can determine the amount of adsorbed nitrate species of the synthesized catalysts by comparing their desorption peak areas of the NO-TPD profiles. It can be clearly observed that the desorption peak area is ranked in the order Fe > FeSi > Nb/FeSi Nb/Fe, which indicates that the introduce of Si or Nb can both inhibit the adsorption of nitrate species. Combing the results of in situ DRIFTs of NO+O2 co-adsorption and NO-TPD, the addition of Nb and Si can weaken the adsorption ability of NO x in the Nb/FeSi catalyst to a certain extent, weakens the thermal stability of nitrate, and releases more NH3 adsorption sites, which is beneficial to improve the NH3-SCR activity of Nb/FeSi catalyst. 3.6 SO2 adsorption properties The in situ DRIFTS characterization of SO2+O2 co-adsorption were conducted at 225 °C to further explore the difference of these prepared catalysts on the SO2 adsorption capacity and the types of the sulfates. As shown in Fig. 10 a, when 1000 ppm SO2 and 5 vol% O2 is introduced into the reaction cell, intense bands (900–1400 cm−1) assigned to the sulfate species could be detected. This indicates that SO2 will adsorb on the catalyst surface and cause sulfate deposition, which will interfere with the stable adsorption of NH3 and other active components on the catalyst and cut off the continuous reduction of NO [47]. Among them, the peak at 1080 cm−1 and 996 cm−1 is attributed to the symmetrical stretching frequency of O-S-O, and the peak at 1360 cm−1, 1152 cm−1 and 1298 cm−1 is attributed to the asymmetric stretching frequency of OS=O of metal oxide surface sulfate [48,49]. As for FeSi (Fig. 10b), most of the bands in the spectra of Fe2O3 were undetected, and only several weak bands around 1340 cm−1, assigned to a structure with OS=O. This is because that Fe ions in FeSi were bonded to Si-O and the existence of hydroxyl groups, and the deeper sulfation was suppressed. As for Nb/Fe catalyst (Fig. 10c), the detected types of sulfate were the same as Fe2O3, but the adsorption peak strength was significantly weakened, indicating that the surface acid site brought about by the introduction of Nb also inhibited the adsorption of SO2.With regard with Nb/FeSi catalyst (Fig. 10d), only very weak infrared peaks can be observed, which is mainly due to the presence of hydroxyl groups on the surface of Nb/FeSi catalyst and the combined effect of surface acid sites. Therefore, it can be inferred that the increase of surface acid sites and the presence of hydroxyl groups can help Nb/FeSi exhibit excellent sulfur resistance by inhibiting the adsorption of SO2. 3.7 Reaction mechanism The NH3-SCR reaction mechanism on the Nb/FeSi catalyst surface was explored by in situ DRIFTS experiment. As shown in Fig. 11, The reactions of NH3 between pre-adsorbed NO+O2 and NO + O2 between pre-adsorbed NH3 as a function of time were studied. After NH3 adsorption at 250 ℃, some infrared bands attributed to adsorbed NH3 species at Lewis acid sites (1609 cm−1) and Brønsted acid sites (1689 and 1434 cm−1) were observed on Nb/FeSi surface [50]. When the NO+O2 was introduced, both the ionic NH4 + species located at Brønsted acid sites (1689 and 1434 cm−1) and coordinated NH3 species adsorbed Lewis acid sites (1609 cm−1) disappeared due to the reaction with gas NO [51–53]. That is to say, the NH3-SCR reaction on Nb/FeSi could be efficiently carried out through the E-R mechanism reaction pathway during which the gaseous NO could directly react with adsorbed active NH3 species. More noteworthy is that the consumption rate of the ionic NH4 + species on Brønsted acid sites is faster, indicating that the ionic NH4 + species on the Nb/FeSi catalyst have higher reaction activity than the coordinated NH3 species on the Lewis acid sites. Therefore, it can be concluded that the more Brønsted acid sites and the weakened NO x adsorption capacity of Nb/FeSi catalyst are the main reason for its high its high NH3-SCR activity. To identify the reactivity of adsorbed nitrate species on the surface of Nb/FeSi catalyst, NH3 species were once again introduced into the gas cell, allowing the intensity of the peak at 1435 cm−1 to greatly increase, while the bands assigned to adsorbed nitrates showed no obvious change, indicating that adsorbed nitrate species were not the active species. This further indicates that the weakened nitrate adsorption capacity of Nb/FeSi catalyst is beneficial for the improvement of its NH3-SCR activity. The reactions of NH3 between pre-adsorbed NO+O2 and NO + O2 between pre-adsorbed NH3 as a function of time on Fe, Nb/Fe, and Nb/FeSi catalysts were studied and the results are shown in Fig. S8. Similar experimental conclusions are obtained, indicating that the NH3-SCR reaction proceeds following to the E-R mechanism. 4 Conclusion In summary, catalysts of NbO x supported on Si doped Fe2O3 composite oxide were synthesized and the effect of modification of Nb and Si on NH3-SCR performance of Nb/FeSi catalyst was studied. It is found that the doping of Si can inhibit the crystal phase formation of Fe2O3, greatly increase the specific surface area and at the same time bring a large number of hydroxyl groups, which makes Nb/FeSi catalyst has more Brønsted acid sites. The surface modification of Nb increases the amount of active oxygen species and acid sites, and significantly suppressed the peroxidation of NH3 and the adsorption of surface nitrate. Moreover, the increase of surface acid sites and the presence of hydroxyl groups help Nb/FeSi exhibit excellent sulfur resistance by inhibiting the adsorption of SO2. and helps to inhibit the adsorption of SO2. DRIFTS results show that NH3-SCR reaction of Nb/FeSi catalyst follows E-R mechanism, which is also an important reason why SO2 has little influence on its NH3-SCR activity. Our work provides reference for designing high-performance denitrification catalysts based on the role of different components in NH3-SCR catalytic performance. coredata.dc:description: The widespread application of Fe-based denitrification catalysts is limited by its unsatisfying low-temperature NO conversion and poor anti-SO2 ability. In this study, by virtue of FeSi composite oxide with large specific surface area as support and NbO x species was used for surface modification to further regulate their acidity and redox properties, significantly improving their NH3-SCR activity. The optimal Nb/FeSi catalyst exhibited over 90 % NO conversion at 250–400 °C and displayed excellent SO2 resistance at 225 °C. The characterization results revealed that Si doping induced an amorphous structure in the FeSi composite and facilitated the formation of distinctive Fe-O–Si bonding configurations. These structural features endowed the Nb/FeSi catalyst with both an enlarged specific surface area and increased Brønsted acid sites, facilitating the dispersion of active components and the activation of NH3 species. Nb could promote the generation of more oxygen vacancies and abundant Brønsted acid sites while inhibits the adsorption of NO x and SO2. Further mechanistic studies revealed that the enhanced Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism, where gaseous NO directly reacts with adsorbed NH₃, significantly promoted the NH₃-SCR efficiency of Nb/FeSi. This work provides experimental guidance to improve the activity and sulfur resistance of denitration catalyst by active component control.
